The total population on earth is really dependent on food and usable nitrogen. This has already been artificially increased with the Haber-Bosch process, that allowed the world's population to explode from 1.8 billion to 8 billion from 1900 to today. This is well above what is sustainable through natural farming.

The Haber-Bosch process allowed for usable nitrogen be extracted from the air to generate ammonia that would provide exceptional fertilizer for food production and nitrates for explosives that fueled that the war industry.

If the world's population continues to grow we have to hope that science provides the answer as to more living space and farming; or if there is another process for increasing food yield even further.

I did some calculating myself. Kurzgesagct made a video on a similar subject and they claimed the energy of the galaxy has enough energy for a tredecillion (10^42) human lives as we understand a human life today. I hunted around and I found the hubble volume is about 2% of the observable universe, which is the portion of the universe we can ever reach. The hubble volume therefore contains about five billion galaxies. A researcher estimated that the average galaxy has about 100 million stars while the milky way has about 100-400 billion stars. I decided to go with 100 billion so I could do the numbers in my head. So we have a tredecillion human lives divided by a thousand to find the average human lives a galaxy can support times five billion galaxies in the hubble volumes gives me five quindecillion humans that can ever live.

That's 5x10^48.

Then if we accept the fact that humans will change in the future, things get wacky, as if they weren't already. According to an Isaac Arthur episode, a computer with the mass of a galactic super cluster running at the Landour limit can simulate 10^80 human lives. That's about as many humans as there are particles in the universe. I don't remember the episode that explains this though. Probably one about civilizations at the end of time.

Fun fact, if mind uploading is possible, we might be able to survive 10^1500 years into the future. Even if the computers hosting our minds had to run at one trillionth of real time, we would still get 10^1486 years of living. Neat.

I usually really like your content, but this video felt like I was being sold a narrative.
Normally, you present information about scientific concepts - making descriptive claims.
In this video the content leads up to prescriptive claims about the course of humanity and what should be done.
When you revealed that this video was sponsored by Will MacAskill, it clicked for me.

What you have done here (and I have no doubt you weren't trying to do so consciously) is propaganda.
You have presented the specific things MacAskill / the CEA (who are effectively a think tank) advocate for.
If you were trying to make a video agreeing with their advocacy, you should make clear you are not presenting science (as one would assume from every single other video you have done), but a political opinion.

Some of the advocacy here is really controversial.
For example, "What We Owe Our Future" arguing that AI may be as much of a threat as climate change (incidentally, in your list of existential threats AI comes before climate change, too) which I don't think I need to explain why one might take issue with this.
Furthermore phrasings like "continue moral progress" imply a lot about the nature of human history. Mainly that we are on a linear-ish trajectory of progress - a much disagreed upon theory, but also has some other issues that are more complicated to point out without getting into more in-depth sociology.
Another one is "develop economically". This is by no means just objectively good, but posed as such in the video - same as "devolop institutions" (maybe some institutions should be abolished instead?)
Again, I'm not trying to say you aren't allowed to advocate for these points. I am simply trying to show that what you are doing is making prescriptive claims about what is to be done for humanity - which is very explicitly political content.

I am not arguing that you cannot make political content, I am criticizing the (on your part unintentional) deceptive framing of political advocacy as science / science communication.
This is by no means an issue that is unique to this video. Other content creators doing videos about science / science communication have done this, too (a recent example being the kurzgesagt video "Is Civilization on the Brink of Collapse?", sponsored by the same person).
Big content creators like you have a lot of responsibility to present content accurately and sponsorships/ads are one of the ways in which it is easiest for political actors to promote their own interests in a deceptive manner (in other words propagandize) using your influence.
If you want to understand this phenomenon better, I would recommend watching "Johnny Harris: A Story of YouTube Propaganda" by Tom Nicholas (I'm going to refrain from posting links because that might get flagged as spam).

I really hope you take my criticism to heart because I think as a science communicator you have an important role educating people and I think your regular content is very high-quality. As such I'd be frustrated if you let your content get turned into propaganda.

The statement that the human population will grow until it reaches carrying capacity is wrong. The rate of population growth in the world has already started to slow down even though we are reasonably far away from the carrying capacity.

The reason for this is because as the prosperity of human environments goes up, the number of people who want to have children goes down for a number of reasons. This is especially true nowadays because of better protection and prevention methods.

An example of this is in the UK sometime around the 1800s when the industrial Revolution started. People were poor but having large numbers of children and people were worried that they couldn’t support the number of people and suggested population control. This was until the benefits of the industrial Revolution started to come through; people started living better lives and stopped having as much children

3:05: Note that the Malthusian Trap is a simplified version of reality. Now, if we can't figure out some way to live in space, we are limited to a finite carrying capacity*, but that carrying capacity depends on a wide range of factors that Malthus didn't consider.
To take a simple example: Even without changing available technology, trade can greatly increase the carrying capacity of a region, since it allows sub-regions to specialize in the crops that grow best there (rather than needing to grow everything you need within a day's walk of home).

*Technically I guess we're still limited to a finite carrying capacity if we do figure out how to live in space, it's just a carrying capacity large enough that we'll likely run out of stars and other energy sources before we reach it.

Thought experiment: say you wake up in a prison cell and the only information you have is that you're in room number 23, and that all the rooms are individually numbered. How many cells does the prison have? On one level, you fundamentally don't know. But how likely is it that the prison has 100 cells compared to 10,000? If you get your computer to pick a random number from 1 to 10,000, would you reasonably expect 23? What about a million cells? We can conclude that, while we don't know, it's more likely that the prison is small.

So, how likely is it that you're roughly in the first ~100bn people if there will eventually be ~100qn? If everyone dies tomorrow, there was already only a 6% chance you're born now. The chances if there are 100qn are more like winning the lottery every week for the rest of your life by sheer chance*. Is that a reasonable expectation?

There, a logically flawless argument concluding we're all going to die soon. You're welcome. The next time you see a guy sporting a "the end is nigh" billboard, give him the thumbs up.

Keep in mind though with the "typical mammalian species" thing, what about a typical mammalian genus? Humans are not just a species but the only representatives of a genus that was diverse before our species came along and outcompeted/destroyed those other members of our genus. A hyper-invasive species representing a genus that has so far lasted 3 million years, and a clade lasting 7 million years, would not be expected to end in 1 million years. Especially not when its own expansion is the sole reason that genus is no longer diverse. The "typical mammalian species" argument falls flat when you realize just how atypical humans are as a mammalian species even from a purely ecological and cladistic standpoint. Hyperinvasive generalists outcompeting their entire 7 million year lineage of invasive generalists isn't a sign that they are ecologically fragile with only one species left.

There are some big problems here.
What is humanity's sustainable (for millions of years) population level?
It could be that we will ultimately find that our current population levels are based on unsustainable practices, and our population will eventually undergo a dramatic correction, either by accident or intentionally, as we are forced into living more sustainably.

It could be that we are nowhere near our carrying capacity. And that in fact with a revolution in sustainable food production and such, some countries will quickly expand their population into the tens of billions, and those that don't will follow suit to compete, and there will be a trillion people on Earth for the next hundred million years as they become one of the main lineages in the world, diversifying into numerous forms but retaining most of their ancestral characteristics like tool use, bipedalism, social living, construction of cities, ultra-efficient hydroponic greenhouse agriculture, etc, but might adapt to local niches, or even undergo modification into a complex trophic web with widespread and brutal kleptoparasitism between very different human descendants (not likely predation though). Or perhaps humans would not undergo this adaptive radiation and rapid and global interbreeding would enforce global evolution of the whole species rather than speciation.

Or it could be that there are VAST amounts of unoccupied niche space and carrying capacity sitting above our heads and that humans will expand into an interplanetary, extraplanetary, or interstellar species.

At 2:45 you said about carrying capacity, and while its a useful concept (and certainly better than expecting exponential growth), i think its wrong to assume the same about humans, or at the very least misleading.
Like, sure, if population of monkeys is limited by the amount of fruit trees produce - their population will probably look like sigmoid. But this assumes that all resources are produced regularly\yearly\seasonally, and this is simply not true for humans. Fossil fuels are non-renewable, but because there is a huge backlog of it - human population was limited by how quickly it can be produced. So it acts more like a temporary boost, not a permanent increase in available resources, and according to some people without a constant supply of oil, earth can't support even half of the current population, and instead of a sigmoid graph, you should probably expect a fairy steep decline in population after the peak (if not an extinction)
It's certainly not unheard of to see species go extinct due to similar reasons, so ignoring it in a video about limits of human population feels like something an oil company would do

The estimates expected lifespan in the future seem so naive to me. It feels like the researchers just look at some trends from the average age steadily increasing, project it forward a bit, and call it a day.

Are they factoring in the latest breakthroughs in medicine? Do they account for gene manipulation? What about in 10 years when the smartest possible doctor is cloud-computing based and everyone can be diagnosed for any problems in seconds? Or 10 years after that when more advanced AI can solve any of these problems after diagnosing it?

The graph seems to suggest that they're projecting forward 80 years into the future. If humans exist at all in 80 years does anyone truly believe we'll not have figured out some pretty basic fundamentals of biology where we can fix any problem? In a quarter of that time or less we'll have near perfect simulations where we could test billions of drugs/treatments for short/long term problems etc, and even without any 'intelligence' we could bruteforce medicines and fixes personal to the individual. But we should be considering it more like if AlphaGo was to tackle medicine instead of go. Where no human will ever again be the best at treating conditions, and everyone gets an unhumanly perfect diagnosis every single time. It's a harder and more intricate problem, but considering the exponential increase of technology/AI it's almost a guarantee within 20 years, an absolute certainty in 50 (again; if we don't all die first, which is probably the most likely).

I realise this isn't the point of the video, but just pointing out that we should take projections of population/lifespans with a grain of salt.

Birthrates dropping has nothing to do with "rights" or "education" & everything to do with widespread access to contraceptives. Birthrates have been fairly high throughout all of Human history; however, the mortality rate of infants, mothers, & young children mean that the total deaths/births were substantially higher in these periods, hence why the past population number seems so utterly staggering. In truth, lower birthrates will only persist as long as the global supplychain does. Once contraceptive medications, surgeries, & services are either difficult to access or are straight up forbidden then (barring catastrophe & man-made horrors beyond our comprehension) we'll see birthrates begin to climb across the board.

We will either crawolnize the galaxy or be stuck in the Sol system, unless there's a weird trick to get around the speed limit and causality (physicists hate him!). We can support Earth's population using 1980s tech with only the arable land in California, California of course not being the greatest place for farming. Logistically that wouldn't work, but it's something to keep in mind. With modern methods including the dry/indoor/multilevel farming meme, our population could easily be multiplied by ten without issue. The limit is not ability, rather, it is culture - desire. People increasingly prefer to live in disgusting cities with exorbitant rent over forming large families 30 miles away in cheaper, safer, quieter, lower crime areas.
This may be a hot take, but humanity does not suffer from resource scarcity, we suffer from local resource availability, and in the future we expect to find issues with sustainability. Millions of tons of useful product go to waste each year, these useful prodcuts could have been consumed, yet they became landfills due to logistical economic concern.
I cannot predict future technological innovation, but you should be able to notice the trend (as the video author seems to have done) that population estimates only ever go up. Decades ago, we thought Earth had limited carrying capacity, this mistake has been corrected. One decade ago, we thought birth rates would fall faster. In another decade, increased quality of life, medicine, wages and so on will only increase the estimated number of future people.
Really, there are a short number of possibilities. We could go extinct, we could reach the "end" of knowledge and run out of improvements to make, or we will continually see improvements which inevitably lead to increased populations. As for extinction, the only existential risks that could actually endanger the ability of ALL humans to reproduce are misaligned ASI and stellar issues (such as a burst destoying earth's protections, leaving alive only a few hundred humans who happened to be well underground, but not enough humans for a genetically viable population in the long term).

Being so early in the history of humanity gives us a crazy amount of influence. As time goes on and the populations increase, your likelihood of becoming a legend decreases dramatically. Just think how Aristotle, Hannibal, David, and Ramses are viewed as great heroes, even though compared with today there are probably many with equal or greater skills/accomplishments. Compare this with the Bonapartes, Churchills, Washingtons, and Maos that pop up today. The heroes keep getting rarer and rarer, but also greater and greater as the competition for titles increases. Just how powerful with the "great men" of the future be?

Edit: 76 comments and counting; wow. Let this be a testament to how easily YouTube commenters can artificially insert motive into a mild academic preponderance.
Please note that I'm calling these people "great," not "good." By "great" I mean significant/famous; the kind of person you can read a book about and 90% of literate people are familiar with. Very few people reading the comments actually had to Google who Mao was.
I'm also not insinuating anything about how people become "great." Whether this is by circumstances or by their own ability doesn't matter. Each of these people have had influences across centuries and will continue to influence as long as humanity remains in roughly its current state.
There are more famous people than ever, but most are forgotten within a decade. Will Donald Trump, Taylor Swift, and Pope Francis stand time? All I'm saying is that if they do, they will be statistically less impactful than someone living at the time of Newton, Ghengis Khan, or Columbus.

Unfortunately, the main assumption of this video is wrong. The fertility rate per woman in developed countries is already way below 2 (you can even see this in the diagram at 3:41). That means, the population in those countries is already shrinking (excluding immigration and the effects due an increasing life expectancy). We can assume that we will see the same effect in all countries if they get more and more developed. So the world birthrate will not be 127 million from 2100 on but will steadily decline. Kurzgesagt made the same video a month ago and they also ignored the fact that the world fertility rate will drop below 2 in the next decades. The M1 Abrams is a third-generation American main battle tank designed by Chrysler Defense (now General Dynamics Land Systems) and named for General Creighton Abrams. Conceived for modern armored ground warfare and now one of the heaviest tanks in service at nearly 68 short tons (almost 62 metric tons), it introduced several innovative features, including a multifuel turbine engine, sophisticated Chobham composite armor, a computer fire control system, separate ammunition storage in a blow-out compartment, and NBC protection for crew safety. Initial models of the M1 were armed with a licensed-produced 105 mm Royal Ordnance L7 gun, while later variants feature a licensed Rheinmetall 120 mm L/44.

The M1 Abrams was developed from the failure of the MBT-70 project to replace the obsolescent M60 tank. There are three main operational Abrams versions, the M1, M1A1, and M1A2, with each new iteration seeing improvements in armament, protection, and electronics. Extensive improvements have been implemented to the latest formerly designated M1A2 System Enhancement Package version 3 or SEPv3 and M1A2 SEPv4, respectively versions such as improved composite armor, better optics, digital systems and ammunition. The Abrams was due to be replaced by the Future Combat Systems XM1202 but due to its cancellation, the U.S. military has opted to continue maintaining and operating the M1 series for the foreseeable future by upgrading with improved optics, armor and firepower.

The M1 Abrams entered service in 1980 and currently serves as the main battle tank of the United States Army and formerly the Marine Corps. The export version is used by the armies of Egypt, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Australia, and Iraq. The Abrams was first used in combat in the Persian Gulf War and has seen combat in both the War in Afghanistan and Iraq War under U.S. service, while Iraqi Abrams tanks have seen action in the war against ISIL and have seen use by Saudi Arabia during the Yemeni Civil War.
